Peripheral Vascular: (Right radial pulse: diminished), (Left radial
Abdominal: Soft, Non-tender, Bowel sounds present
Extremities: Right lower extremity edema: 2+, Left lower extremity

self, [**Hospital3 **], ""[**2157**]"", Movement: Not assessed, Tone: Not assessed

%, Eos:0.5 %, Albumin:2.7 g/dL, LDH:415 IU/L, Ca++:7.7 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3
Imaging: CXR:  R PICC line.  Cardiomegaly.  Mild perihilar fullness,
slightly worsened than [**10-16**].  L pleural effusion.
CTA chest/abd--Prelim:  No central PE but singular small PE at LLL ant
basal segment branch point. Left pleural effusion & bibasal
atelectasis.  Nodular consolidation and fluid in trachea and esophagus
susp for aspiration pneumonitis.  No diverticulitis.
Right femur:  Expected postop appearance.  No subcutaneous air.
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Ms. [**Known lastname 10607**] is a 60 yo F with CAD s/p IMI, CHF s/p
AICD, SLE, scleroderma, severe pulmonary HTN, COPD on home O2, C.
difficle colitis, recent admission for R hip fracture s/p ORIF
complicated by urosepsis and respiratory failure who was discharged to
rehab yesterday and returns for respiratory distress.
# Respiratory distress:  Currently at baseline O2 requirements.  Likely
aspiration event in the setting of pulmonary HTN and COPD.  She was
also noted to have nodular consolidation and fluid in trachea and
esophagus susp for aspiration pneumonitis.  Patient has severe
pulmonary hypertension on sildenafil and bosenten.  CXR suggests mild
pulmonary edema, likely worsened by tachycardia (driven by fever,
pain).  CTA chest showed singular small PE at LLL ant basal segment
branch point, left pleural effusion, & bibasal atelectasis.  I do not
- O2 by NC with goal O2 sat of 88-94%.
- cont. pulmonary HTN treatment with sildenafil and viagra
# Fever:  In last 24 hours prior to discharge, Tmax was 99.6.  In last
48 hours prior to discharge, Tmax was 102.1 on [**10-14**].  Leukocytosis
stable from discharge.  She does does have c. diff and was found to
have pan-sensitive Klebsiella/E. colic UTI on appropriate abx since
[**10-9**].  Neg. U/A.  Repeat UCx pending.  She is intermittently tachypneic
to 40s, but CT chest showed no sig. infiltrate.  [**Month (only) 51**] be from
asipration.  Per Ortho, R hip does not appear infected.  There is
erythema just around the incision over her R hip.  PICC line was placed
yesterday and site appears benign.  Other considerations include drug
fever.  She also has a PE but appears small.
- monitor fever curve (note on standing tylenol for pain)
- cont po vanc for C. diff
- hold off on Cipro as UTI has been adequately treated
- low threshold to start treatment for hospital acquired aspiration
pneumonia with vanc/zosyn if HD unstable, leukocytosis worsens.
- US RUE to r/o thrombosis (on anticoagulation anyway)
# Recent urosepsis:  On appropriate abx since [**10-9**].
# C. difficle colitis:  No evidence of megacolon.
- plan for prolonged PO vanco course for 2 weeks after last dose of abx
THEN taper 125mg PO QID X 14 days, 125mg PO BID X 1, 125mg daily x 1
week, 125mg QOD x 1 week, 125mg q3 days x 2 weeks.
# MAT vs afib:  BP stable but HR suboptimally controlled.  Worsened by
fever, PE, post-op pain.  In addition, at rehab she was only given 50
- cont. metoprolol 100 mg [**Hospital1 7**] to improve filling time
- control pain with standing tylenol, limit narcotics
# Elevated troponin:  Likely demand ischemia.  No ischemic EKG changes.
- cont. ASA 81 mg (cannot tolerate higher doses), BB, statin
# Pulmonary HTN c/b R heart failure:  BNP [**Numeric Identifier 10810**].
-gentle diuresis prn to decrease burden on RV
# R Hip Fracture: s/p R ORIF on [**2167-10-8**].
- pain control with standing tylenol, oxycodone prn, and lidocaine
# Mental status:  Likely due to morphine in ED.  Was delirius last
- holding plavix post-op as PCI was in [**2164**]
# FEN: hold IVFs / replete lytes prn / NPO except meds
# PPX: home PPI, lovenox, bowel regimen
Communication: Family meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:

- The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AFib), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), C. difficile colitis, and a recent admission for right hip fracture surgery.
- She was discharged to rehab yesterday but returned due to respiratory distress.

- On admission, her vital signs included a temperature of 101.3°F, heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure of 137/92 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 94% on nasal cannula, and a multifocal atrial tachycardia rhythm.
- She has a history of penicillin and sulfa allergies, as well as an unknown reaction to aspirin.
- Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 12.2 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.0 g/dL, platelet count of 383 K/uL, creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL, and troponin-T level of 0.08.
- Imaging reveals a right pleural effusion, mild perihilar fullness, and a small pulmonary embolism (PE) at the left lower lobe.

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AF), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and C. difficile colitis. She presented to the ICU with respiratory distress and fever. The patient has multiple comorbidities and recent hospitalizations for hip fracture surgery and urosepsis. She was discharged to rehabilitation but returned due to respiratory distress.

1. Aspiration Pneumonitis: The patient's history of COPD, pulmonary hypertension, and recent hip surgery increases the risk of aspiration. The CT chest showed nodular consolidation and fluid in the trachea and esophagus, suggesting possible aspiration event.

2. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The CT angiogram (CTA) revealed a small PE at the left lower lobe ant basal segment branch point. This increases the risk of further embolic events and right ventricular strain.

3. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): Despite appropriate antibiotic treatment for C. difficile and a urinary tract infection (UTI), the patient's fever persists. Other potential causes of FUO should be investigated.
4. Delirium: The patient's mental status changes may be due to morphine in the emergency department or an underlying delirium.

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, severe pulmonary hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, C. difficile colitis, and recent admission for right hip fracture surgery complicated by urosepsis and respiratory failure. She is currently in the ICU due to respiratory distress, fever, and acute pulmonary embolism.
1. Aspiration Pneumonitis: The patient has nodular consolidation and fluid in the trachea and esophagus, which suggests aspiration pneumonitis.
2. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's chest X-ray shows mild pulmonary edema, likely worsened by tachycardia (driven by fever, pain).
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has right lower extremity edema and diminished radial pulses, indicating possible DVT.
4. Klebsiella/E. coli Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The patient has leukocytosis and a positive urine culture for pan-sensitive Klebsiella/E. coli, indicating a UTI.
5. C. difficile Colitis: The patient has C. difficile colitis, which is indicated by abdominal pain, diarrhea, and positive stool test.

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and atrial fibrillation (AFib). She is currently experiencing hypoxemic respiratory distress and altered mental status. The patient also has a fever of 101.3°F, and there is suspicion of aspiration. She has been diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism (PE), and her condition requires close monitoring. The patient has a history of Clostridium difficile infection (C. diff) and Klebsiella urinary tract infection (UTI), which have been treated. Her hip wound is stable without signs of infection.
1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory distress, coupled with known PAH and COPD, increases the risk of further respiratory complications such as pneumonia or exacerbation of COPD.
2. Fevers: The persistent fever despite treatment for C. diff and UTI suggests the possibility of another underlying infection, which needs to be identified and addressed promptly to prevent sepsis.

3. Neurological Status: The patient's waxing and waning mental status could indicate neurological complications like delirium or even seizures. Close observation and further evaluation are necessary to determine the cause and provide appropriate management.
4. Pulmonary Embolism: The acute PE diagnosis poses a risk for further thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Ant"

,Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old female with a chief complaint of hypoxemic respiratory distress. The patient has multiple medical conditions including atrial fibrillation (AFIB), altered mental status, pulmonary embolism (PE), and fever of unknown origin (FUO).

The patient's vital signs indicate a temperature of 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate of 102 beats per minute (bpm) with an irregular rhythm, blood pressure ranging from 120/52 mmHg to 143/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on nasal cannula and face tent.

The patient has been receiving various treatments including antibiotics (vancomycin and cefipime), lansoprazole, enoxaparin (lovenox), hydroxychloroquine, ASA, sildenafil, PPI, metoprolol, and bosentan.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) at 12.2 K/uL, hematocrit (Hct) at 31.0%, platelets (Plt) at 383 K/uL, creatinine (Cr) at 1.0 mg/dL, troponin-T at 0.08 mg/dL, glucose at 130 mg/dL, and other abnormalities in liver enzymes and electrolyte levels.

pulse: Not assessed), (Right DP pulse: Not assessed), (Left DP pulse:

,The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), severe pulmonary hypertension (PH), COPD, C. difficile colitis, recent admission for a right hip fracture surgery with open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF), and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. The patient is currently admitted for respiratory distress, which is believed to be caused by aspiration pneumonitis in the setting of poor nutritional status. The patient also has a history of urosepsis and has been readmitted for respiratory distress.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.3°C (97.3°F), heart rate of 84 beats per minute, blood pressure of 122/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on face tent. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14.6 K/uL, elevated troponin T levels of 0.08 ng/mL, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels of 415 IU/L. Other lab results indicate hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia.
1. Oxygen therapy to maintain oxygen saturation above 88-90%.
2. Broad-spectrum antibiotics pending negative blood culture results.
